translation: The vision of Isaiah son of Amoz, which he saw concerning Judah and Jerusalem in the days of Uzziah, Jotham, Ahaz, and Hezekiah, kings of Judah.
Hear, O heavens, and give ear, O earth, for the LORD has spoken: Sons I have reared and exalted, but they have rebelled against Me.
The ox knows its owner, and the donkey its master’s manger; but Israel does not know, my people do not understand.
Alas, sinful nation, a people heavy with iniquity, seed of evildoers, children who corrupt! They have forsaken the LORD, they have despised the Holy One of Israel, they have turned away backward.
Why will you be struck again? You will only add to your rebellion. The whole head is sick, and the whole heart faint.
From the sole of the foot even to the head there is no soundness in it; wounds, and bruises, and fresh blows—they have not been closed, nor bound up, nor softened with oil.
Your land is a desolation, your cities burned with fire; your soil, before your very eyes, strangers devour it, and it is a desolation, like an overthrow by foreigners.
And the daughter of Zion is left like a shelter in a vineyard, like a lodge in a cucumber field, like a city besieged.
Unless the LORD of hosts had left us a very small remnant, we would have been as Sodom, we would have become like Gomorrah.
Hear the word of the LORD, you rulers of Sodom; give ear to the law of our God, you people of Gomorrah.

“What is the multitude of your sacrifices to Me? says the LORD. I am full of burnt offerings of rams and the fat of well-fed beasts; and in the blood of bulls and lambs and he-goats I do not delight.”
When you come to appear before Me, who has required this from your hand—trampling My courts?
Do not continue to bring a vain offering; incense, it is an abomination to Me. New moon and Sabbath, the calling of assemblies—I cannot endure iniquity and solemn gathering.
Your new moons and your appointed feasts my soul hates; they have become a burden upon me; I am weary of bearing them.
And when you spread out your hands, I will hide My eyes from you; even though you multiply prayer, I will not listen. Your hands are full of blood.
Wash yourselves, make yourselves clean; remove the evil of your deeds from before My eyes; cease to do evil.
Learn to do good; seek justice, correct the oppressor; judge the fatherless, plead for the widow.
Come now, and let us reason together, says the LORD: though your sins are like scarlet, they shall be white as snow; though they are red like crimson, they shall be as wool.
If you are willing and obey, you shall eat the good of the land.
But if you refuse and rebel, you shall be devoured by the sword; for the mouth of the LORD has spoken.
How the faithful city has become a harlot, she who was full of justice! Righteousness lodged in her, but now murderers.
Your silver has become dross, your wine is mixed with water.
Your princes are rebellious and companions of thieves; every one of them loves a bribe and chases after rewards. They do not judge the fatherless, and the widow’s cause does not come before them.
Therefore thus says the Lord, the LORD of hosts, the Mighty One of Israel: Ah, I will be comforted from my adversaries, and I will take vengeance on my enemies.
And I will turn my hand upon you, and will smelt away your dross as with lye, and remove all your alloy.
And I will restore your judges as at the first, and your counselors as at the beginning; after this you shall be called the city of righteousness, the faithful town.
Zion shall be redeemed with justice, and her returning ones with righteousness.
But the destruction of transgressors and sinners shall be together, and those who forsake the LORD shall come to an end.
For you shall be ashamed of the terebinths which you have desired, and you shall be confounded because of the gardens that you have chosen.
For you shall be as an oak whose leaf withers, and as a garden that has no water.
And the strong shall be as tinder, and his work as a spark; and they shall both burn together, and none shall quench them.
The word that Isaiah son of Amoz saw concerning Judah and Jerusalem.

And it shall come to pass in the latter days, that the mountain of the house of the LORD shall be established as the head of the mountains, and shall be lifted up above the hills; and all the nations shall stream to it.

And many peoples shall go and say, Come, and let us go up to the mountain of the LORD, to the house of the God of Jacob; and He will teach us of His ways, and we will walk in His paths. For out of Zion shall go forth instruction, and the word of the LORD from Jerusalem.

And he shall judge between the nations, and shall decide for many peoples; and they shall beat their swords into plowshares, and their spears into pruning hooks. Nation shall not lift up sword against nation, neither shall they learn war any more.
O house of Jacob, come, and let us walk in the light of the LORD.

For you have forsaken your people, the house of Jacob, because they are filled with customs from the east, and practice divination like the Philistines, and clasp hands with the children of foreigners.
Their land is filled with silver and gold, and there is no end to their treasures; their land is filled with horses, and there is no end to their chariots.
And his land is filled with idols; they bow down to the work of their own hands, to that which their own fingers have made.
So man is brought low, and humankind is humbled; therefore do not forgive them.
Enter into the rock, and hide yourself in the dust, from before the terror of the LORD and from the splendor of His majesty.
The lofty eyes of man shall be brought low, and the haughtiness of men shall be bowed down, and the LORD alone shall be exalted in that day.
For the day of the LORD of hosts shall be upon all that is proud and lofty, and upon all that is lifted up, and it shall be brought low.
And upon all the cedars of Lebanon, high and lifted up, and upon all the oaks of Bashan.
And upon all the high mountains, and upon all the lifted up hills.
And upon every high tower, and upon every fortified wall.
And upon all the ships of Tarshish, and upon all the splendid craft of delight.
And the haughtiness of man shall be bowed down, and the loftiness of men shall be brought low; and the LORD alone shall be exalted in that day.
And the idols shall utterly pass away.
And they shall go into the caves of the rocks, and into the holes of the dust, from before the terror of the LORD and from the splendor of His majesty, when He arises to shake the earth.
In that day a man shall cast away his idols of silver and his idols of gold, which they made for him to bow down to, to the moles and to the bats.
To go into the clefts of the rocks, and into the crannies of the cliffs, from before the terror of the LORD and from the splendor of His majesty, when He arises to shake the earth.
Cease from man, whose breath is in his nostrils; for of what account is he?
For behold, the Lord, the LORD of hosts, is removing from Jerusalem and from Judah support and staff, every support of bread and every support of water.
The mighty man and the man of war, the judge and the prophet, and the diviner and the elder.
captain of fifty, and one held in esteem, and counselor, and skillful craftsman, and expert enchanter.
And I will make youths their princes, and capricious ones shall rule over them.
And the people shall oppress, each man his fellow and each man his neighbor; the youth shall act arrogantly against the elder, and the base against the honorable.
When a man shall seize his brother of his father’s house, saying, “You have a cloak; you be our ruler, and let this ruin be under your hand.”
He shall lift up his voice in that day, saying, I will not be a binder of wounds; and in my house is neither bread nor garment. Do not make me a ruler of the people.
For Jerusalem has stumbled, and Judah has fallen, because their tongue and their deeds are against the LORD, to provoke the eyes of His glory.
The look on their faces testifies against them, and they declare their sin like Sodom; they do not hide it. Woe to their soul, for they have brought evil upon themselves.
Say of the righteous, that it is well; for they shall eat the fruit of their deeds.
Woe to the wicked, it is evil with him; for the recompense of his hands shall be done to him.
My people—oppressors strip them, and women rule over them. My people, your guides lead you astray, and the way of your paths they have swallowed up.
The LORD stands up to contend, and stands to judge the peoples.
The LORD will enter into judgment with the elders of His people and its princes, for you have devoured the vineyard; the plunder of the poor is in your houses.
What do you mean that you crush My people and grind the faces of the poor? declares the Lord GOD of hosts.
And the LORD says, Because the daughters of Zion are haughty and walk with outstretched necks and wanton eyes, walking and mincing as they go, and with their feet they make tinkling.
Therefore the Lord will strike with a scab the crown of the head of the daughters of Zion, and the LORD will lay bare their secret parts.
In that day the Lord will take away the finery of the anklets, and the headbands, and the crescent ornaments.
the pendants, and the bracelets, and the veils.
the headdresses, and the anklets, and the sashes, and the houses of the soul, and the enchantments
the rings and the nose-jewels
the festival robes, and the mantles, and the shawls, and the purses.
the mirrors, and the fine linen garments, and the turbans, and the veils.

And it shall come to pass, instead of sweet fragrance there shall be rottenness; and instead of a belt, a rope; and instead of well-set hair, baldness; and instead of a rich robe, a girding of sackcloth; branding instead of beauty.
Your men shall fall by the sword, and your mighty ones in the battle.
Her gates shall lament and mourn, and she, desolate, shall sit upon the ground.
And seven women shall take hold of one man in that day, saying, “We will eat our own bread and wear our own garments; only let your name be called upon us; take away our reproach.”
In that day the Branch of the LORD shall be for beauty and for glory, and the fruit of the earth for majesty and for splendor to the remnant of Israel.
And it shall come to pass, that he who is left in Zion, and he who remains in Jerusalem, shall be called holy, everyone who is written among the living in Jerusalem.
When the Lord has washed away the filth of the daughters of Zion, and has rinsed from her midst the bloodshed of Jerusalem, by a spirit of judgment and by a spirit of burning.

And the LORD will create over every dwelling place of Mount Zion, and over her assemblies, a cloud by day and smoke, and the shining of a flaming fire by night; for over all the glory there will be a canopy.
And there shall be a booth for shade by day from the heat, and for a refuge and for a hiding place from storm and from rain.
Let me sing now for my beloved, a song of my beloved concerning his vineyard: My beloved had a vineyard on a very fertile hill.

And he fenced it round, and cleared it of stones, and planted it with a choice vine; and he built a tower in the midst of it, and also hewed out a winepress in it; and he looked for it to bring forth grapes, but it brought forth wild grapes.
And now, O inhabitant of Jerusalem and man of Judah, judge, I pray you, between me and my vineyard.
What more was there to do for My vineyard that I have not done in it? Why, when I looked for it to yield grapes, did it bring forth wild grapes?
And now I will make known to you what I am about to do to My vineyard: I will remove its hedge, and it shall be consumed; I will break down its wall, and it shall be trampled underfoot.
And I will make it a desolation; it shall not be pruned nor hoed, but brier and thorn shall come up, and I will command the clouds that they rain no rain upon it.

For the vineyard of the LORD of hosts is the house of Israel, and the men of Judah are the planting of His delight; and He looked for justice, but behold, bloodshed; for righteousness, but behold, a cry of distress.
Woe to those who join house to house, who bring field near to field, till there is no more place, and you are made to dwell alone in the midst of the land.
In my ears the LORD of hosts has sworn: Surely many houses shall become desolate, great and fair ones, without inhabitant.
For ten yoke of vineyard shall yield but one bath, and the seed of a homer shall yield but an ephah.
Woe to those who rise early in the morning to pursue strong drink, who linger into the evening till wine inflames them.
And the harp and the lyre, the tambourine and the flute and wine are in their feasts; but the work of the LORD they do not regard, and the deeds of His hands they do not see.
Therefore My people go into exile for lack of knowledge; and their glory are men famished with hunger, and their multitude parched with thirst.
Therefore Sheol has enlarged its appetite and opened its mouth without measure; and her splendor shall go down, and her multitude, and her tumult, and the one who exults in her.
So man is bowed down, and mankind is brought low, and the eyes of the lofty are humbled.
But the LORD of hosts is exalted in judgment, and the Holy God shows Himself holy in righteousness.
Then shall the lambs feed as in their pasture, and in the waste places of the fat ones shall strangers eat.
Woe to those who draw iniquity with cords of vanity, and sin as with cart-ropes.
Who say, “Let Him make speed, let Him hasten His work, that we may see it; and let the counsel of the Holy One of Israel draw near and come, that we may know it.”
Woe to those who call evil good, and good evil; who put darkness for light, and light for darkness; who put bitter for sweet, and sweet for bitter.
Woe to those who are wise in their own eyes, and prudent in their own sight.
Woe to the mighty men at drinking wine, and to the men of valor in mixing strong drink.
Who justify the wicked for a bribe, and take away the righteousness of the righteous from him.

Therefore, as the tongue of fire devours stubble, and as dry grass sinks down in flame, so their root shall be as rottenness, and their blossom shall go up like dust; because they have rejected the law of the LORD of hosts, and despised the word of the Holy One of Israel.

Therefore the anger of the LORD burned against His people, and He stretched out His hand against them and struck them; and the mountains trembled, and their corpses were like refuse in the midst of the streets. In all this His anger has not turned away, and His hand is still outstretched.
And he will lift up a banner to the nations from far away, and will whistle for them from the ends of the earth; and behold, swiftly, speedily they shall come.
None is weary, and none stumbles among them; none slumbers or sleeps; neither is the belt of his loins loosed, nor the strap of his sandals broken.
Whose arrows are sharp, and all his bows bent; whose horses’ hoofs are reckoned like flint, and his wheels like the whirlwind.
Their roaring is like a lion; like young lions they roar and growl, and they seize the prey and carry it away, and there is none to deliver.
And he shall roar against it in that day like the roaring of the sea; and if one look to the land, behold, darkness and distress, and the light is darkened in its clouds.
In the year of King Uzziah’s death, I saw the Lord sitting upon a throne, high and lifted up, and the train of His robe filled the temple.
Seraphim stood above him; each one had six wings: with two he covered his face, and with two he covered his feet, and with two he flew.
And one called to another and said, Holy, holy, holy is the LORD of hosts; the whole earth is full of His glory.
And the foundations of the thresholds shook at the voice of the one who called, and the house was filled with smoke.
And I said, Woe is me, for I am undone; for I am a man of unclean lips, and I dwell in the midst of a people of unclean lips; for my eyes have seen the King, the LORD of hosts.
Then one of the seraphim flew to me, and in his hand was a burning coal that he had taken with tongs from off the altar.
And he touched my mouth and said, Behold, this has touched your lips; and your iniquity is taken away, and your sin is atoned for.
And I heard the voice of the Lord saying, Whom shall I send, and who will go for us? Then I said, Here am I; send me.
And he said, Go, and say to this people: Hear indeed, but do not understand; and see indeed, but do not know.

Make the heart of this people fat, and make their ears heavy, and smear over their eyes; lest they see with their eyes, and hear with their ears, and understand with their heart, and turn again, and be healed.
Then I said, “Until when, Lord?” And He said, “Until cities lie waste without inhabitant, and houses without man, and the land is left utterly desolate.”
And the LORD has removed man far away, and great is the forsakenness in the midst of the land.

Yet there shall still be in it a tenth, and it shall return and shall be for burning, like the terebinth and like the oak, which, when felled, have a stump remaining in them; the holy seed is its stump.

And it came to pass in the days of Ahaz son of Jotham, son of Uzziah, king of Judah, that Rezin king of Aram and Pekah son of Remaliah, king of Israel, went up to Jerusalem to wage war against it, but he was not able to fight against it.
And it was told to the house of David, saying, Aram has encamped upon Ephraim. And his heart was shaken, and the heart of his people, as the trees of the forest are shaken before the wind.
And the LORD said to Isaiah, Go out now to meet Ahaz, you and Shear-jashub your son, at the end of the conduit of the upper pool, on the highway of the fuller’s field.

And you shall say to him, Guard yourself and be calm; do not fear, and let your heart not be faint because of these two tails of smoking firebrands, for the burning anger of Rezin and Aram and the son of Remaliah.
Because Aram has counseled evil against you, with Ephraim and the son of Remaliah, saying,
Let us go up against Judah and terrify it, and let us breach it for ourselves, and set up a king in its midst, even the son of Tabeel.
Thus says the Lord GOD: It shall not stand, nor shall it come to pass.
For the head of Aram is Damascus, and the head of Damascus is Rezin; and within sixty and five years Ephraim shall be broken, that it be not a people.
And the head of Ephraim is Samaria, and the head of Samaria is the son of Remaliah. If you do not believe, surely you shall not be established.
And the LORD spoke again to Ahaz, saying,
Ask for yourself a sign from the LORD your God; make it deep as Sheol, or make it high above.
But Ahaz said, I will not ask, neither will I test the LORD.
And he said, Hear now, O house of David: Is it a small thing for you to weary men, that you will weary also my God?
Therefore the Lord Himself will give you a sign: behold, the virgin is with child and is bearing a son, and she shall call his name Immanuel.
Curds and honey he shall eat, when he knows to refuse the evil and choose the good.
For before the boy knows to refuse the evil and choose the good, the land whose two kings you dread shall be forsaken.
The LORD will bring upon you, and upon your people, and upon your father’s house, days such as have not come from the day that Ephraim departed from Judah, even the king of Assyria.
And it shall come to pass in that day, that the LORD shall whistle for the fly that is at the end of the streams of Egypt, and for the bee that is in the land of Assyria.
And they shall come and settle, all of them, in the steep ravines and in the clefts of the rocks, and upon all the thornbushes and upon all the pastures.
In that day the Lord will shave with a hired razor, from beyond the River, with the king of Assyria, the head and the hair of the feet, and it will also sweep away the beard.
And it shall come to pass in that day, that a man shall keep alive a young cow and two sheep.
And it shall come to pass, from the abundance of the milk that they give, that he shall eat curds; for curds and honey shall everyone eat who is left in the midst of the land.
And it shall come to pass in that day, that every place where there were a thousand vines worth a thousand pieces of silver shall be for briers and for thorns.
With arrows and with bow shall one come there, for briars and thorns shall the whole land become.
And on all the mountains that were hoed with the hoe, there shall not come there the fear of brier and thorn; but it shall be for the sending forth of oxen, and for the treading of sheep.
And the LORD said to me, Take for yourself a great tablet, and write on it with a man’s stylus: Maher-shalal-hash-baz.
And I will take to myself faithful witnesses, Uriah the priest and Zechariah son of Jeberechiah.
And I went in to the prophetess, and she conceived and bore a son. And the LORD said to me, Call his name Maher-shalal-hash-baz.
For before the boy knows how to cry, “My father” and “My mother,” the wealth of Damascus and the spoil of Samaria shall be carried away before the king of Assyria.
And the LORD spoke also to me again, saying:
Because this people has rejected the waters of Shiloah that flow gently, and rejoices in Rezin and the son of Remaliah,

Therefore, behold, the Lord is bringing up upon them the mighty and abundant waters of the River, the king of Assyria and all his glory; and it shall rise over all its channels and go over all its banks.
And it shall sweep through Judah, overflowing and passing over; it shall reach even to the neck. And the outspread wings of it shall be the fullness of the breadth of your land, O Immanuel.
Rage, O peoples, and be shattered; give ear, all you farthest parts of the earth. Gird yourselves, and be shattered; gird yourselves, and be shattered.
Take counsel together, and it shall be brought to nothing; speak the word, and it shall not stand, for God is with us.
For thus the LORD spoke to me with a strong hand, and disciplined me from walking in the way of this people, saying:
You shall not say, “Conspiracy,” to all that this people calls “Conspiracy”; and their fear you shall not fear, nor be in dread of it.
The LORD of hosts, him you shall sanctify; and let him be your fear, and let him be your dread.
And he shall be for a sanctuary, and for a stone of stumbling and for a rock of offense to both houses of Israel, for a snare and for a trap to the inhabitant of Jerusalem.
And many shall stumble on them, and shall fall and be broken, and shall be snared and taken.
Bind up the testimony, seal the teaching among my disciples.
And I will wait for the LORD, who hides His face from the house of Jacob, and I will hope in Him.
Behold, I and the children whom the LORD has given me are for signs and for wonders in Israel, from the LORD of hosts, who dwells on Mount Zion.
And when they say to you, “Seek to the mediums and to the spiritists who chirp and mutter,” should not a people seek to their God? Should they seek on behalf of the living to the dead?
To the law and to the testimony: if they do not speak according to this word, it is because there is no dawn for them.
And he shall pass through it, hard-pressed and hungry; and it shall be, when he is hungry, that he will be enraged and curse his king and his God, and he will turn his face upward.
And he shall look to the earth, and behold, distress and darkness, gloom of anguish; and into thick darkness he shall be driven.

For there shall be no gloom for her that was in anguish. In the former time he made light of the land of Zebulun and the land of Naphtali, but in the latter time he has made glorious the way of the sea, beyond the Jordan, Galilee of the nations.
The people walking in darkness have seen a great light; those dwelling in the land of the shadow of death, upon them a light has shone.
You have multiplied the nation, you have increased its joy; they rejoice before you as with the joy of harvest, as men exult when they divide the spoil.
For the yoke of his burden, and the staff upon his shoulder, the rod of his oppressor, you have shattered as in the day of Midian.
For every boot of the warrior that marches with tumult, and every garment rolled in blood, shall be for burning, fuel for the fire.
For a child is born to us, a son is given to us, and the government shall be upon his shoulder; and his name shall be called Wonderful Counselor, Mighty God, Everlasting Father, Prince of Peace.

Of the increase of the government and of peace there shall be no end, upon the throne of David and upon his kingdom, to establish it and to uphold it with judgment and with righteousness, from this time forth and to eternity. The zeal of the LORD of hosts will perform this.
A word the Lord sent into Jacob, and it fell upon Israel.
And all the people shall know, Ephraim and the inhabitant of Samaria, who say in pride and in greatness of heart,
Bricks have fallen, but we will build with hewn stone; sycamores are cut down, but we will replace them with cedars.
The LORD shall raise up the adversaries of Rezin against him, and shall stir up his enemies.
Aram from the east and the Philistines from behind, and they devour Israel with open mouth. In all this His anger is not turned away, and His hand is still outstretched.
But the people did not turn back to Him who struck them, and the LORD of hosts they did not seek.
So the LORD will cut off from Israel head and tail, palm branch and reed, in one day.
The elder and honored of face, he is the head; and the prophet who teaches falsehood, he is the tail.
And the leaders of this people cause them to err, and those who are led by them are swallowed up.

Therefore the Lord shall not rejoice over their young men, and on their orphans and their widows He shall have no compassion; for every one of them is profane and an evildoer, and every mouth speaks folly. In all this His anger is not turned away, and His hand is still outstretched.
For wickedness burns like a fire; it devours brier and thorn, and it kindles in the thickets of the forest, and they roll upward in towering columns of smoke.
By the wrath of the LORD of hosts the land is burned up, and the people shall be as fuel for the fire; no man will spare his brother.
And he shall cut down on the right hand, and be hungry; and he shall eat on the left hand, and they shall not be satisfied; each man shall eat the flesh of his own arm.
Manasseh devours Ephraim, and Ephraim Manasseh; together they are against Judah. In all this His anger is not turned away, and His hand is still outstretched.
Woe to those who decree unrighteous decrees, and to the writers who write out trouble.
To turn aside the cause of the poor, and to rob the justice of the afflicted of My people; that widows may be their spoil, and that they may plunder the fatherless.
And what will you do in the day of visitation, and in the desolation that shall come from afar? To whom will you flee for help, and where will you leave your glory?
Nothing remains but to crouch among the prisoners, and to fall among the slain. In all this His anger has not turned away, and His hand is still outstretched.
Woe to Assyria, the rod of My anger; and the staff in their hand is My indignation.
Against a profane nation I will send him, and against the people of My wrath I will command him, to seize spoil and to carry off plunder, and to make them a trampling, like the mire of the streets.
But he does not so intend, and his heart does not so reckon; for it is in his heart to destroy, and to cut off nations not a few.
For he says, “Are not my princes altogether kings?”
Is not Calno like Carchemish? Is not Hamath like Arpad? Is not Samaria like Damascus?
As my hand has found the kingdoms of the idols, whose carved images were greater than those of Jerusalem and of Samaria,
Shall I not, as I have done to Samaria and her idols, so do to Jerusalem and her graven images?

And it shall come to pass, when the Lord has finished all His work upon Mount Zion and on Jerusalem, that I will punish the fruit of the proud heart of the king of Assyria, and the glory of the haughtiness of his eyes.

For he has said, “By the strength of my hand I have done it, and by my wisdom, for I am prudent; and I have removed the boundaries of peoples, and have plundered their treasures, and I have brought down, like a mighty one, those who sit enthroned.”
And my hand has found, like a nest, the wealth of the peoples; and as one gathers abandoned eggs, all the earth I gathered, and there was none that fluttered a wing, or opened the mouth, or chirped.

Shall the axe boast itself against him who hews with it, or shall the saw magnify itself against him who wields it? As if a rod should brandish him who lifts it up, as if a staff should lift up that which is not wood.
Therefore the Lord, the LORD of hosts, will send leanness among his fat ones, and under his glory there shall burn a burning like the burning of fire.
And the light of Israel shall be for a fire, and his Holy One for a flame; and it shall burn and devour his thorns and his briers in one day.
And He shall consume the glory of his forest and of his fruitful field, from soul even to flesh; and it shall be as when a sick man wastes away.
And the remnant of the trees of his forest shall be so few in number that a child may write them down.

And it shall come to pass in that day, that the remnant of Israel, and those who have escaped of the house of Jacob, shall no more again lean upon him that struck them, but shall lean upon the LORD, the Holy One of Israel, in truth.
A remnant shall return, a remnant of Jacob, to the Mighty God.
For though your people, O Israel, be as the sand of the sea, only a remnant of them shall return; a destruction is decreed, overflowing with righteousness.
For a full end, and that determined, the Lord, the LORD of hosts, is bringing to pass in the midst of all the earth.

Therefore thus says the Lord GOD of hosts: Do not fear, O My people who dwell in Zion, because of Assyria; with the rod he shall strike you, and his staff he shall lift up against you, after the manner of Egypt.
For yet a very little while, and the indignation shall be finished, and My anger shall turn to their destruction.
And the LORD of hosts will brandish over him a scourge, as in the slaughter of Midian at the rock of Oreb; and his staff will be over the sea, and he will lift it up as in the way of Egypt.
And it shall come to pass in that day, that his burden shall depart from off your shoulder, and his yoke from off your neck, and the yoke shall be destroyed because of the anointing.
He has come upon Aiath, he has passed through Migron; at Michmash he entrusts his baggage.
They have crossed over the pass; Geba is a lodging place for us. Ramah trembles; Gibeah of Saul has fled.
Cry aloud with your voice, O daughter of Gallim; listen, O Laishah; poor Anathoth!
Madmenah is in flight; the inhabitants of Gebim have taken refuge.
Yet this very day he will stand at Nob; he will wave his hand against the mount of the daughter of Zion, the hill of Jerusalem.
Behold, the Lord, the LORD of hosts, is lopping the boughs with terror; and the high of stature shall be hewn down, and the lofty shall be brought low.
And He shall cut down the thickets of the forest with iron, and Lebanon shall fall by the Mighty One.
And there shall come forth a shoot from the stump of Jesse, and a branch from his roots shall bear fruit.
And the Spirit of the LORD shall rest upon him, the spirit of wisdom and understanding, the spirit of counsel and might, the spirit of knowledge and of the fear of the LORD.
His delight shall be in the fear of the LORD, and he shall not judge by the sight of his eyes, nor reprove by the hearing of his ears.

But with righteousness he shall judge the poor, and with equity he shall decide for the meek of the earth; and he shall strike the earth with the rod of his mouth, and with the breath of his lips he shall slay the wicked.
Righteousness shall be the belt of his loins, and faithfulness the belt of his waist.
And the wolf shall sojourn with the lamb, and the leopard shall lie down with the young goat; and the calf and the young lion and the fatling together, and a little child shall lead them.
And the cow and the bear shall feed; together their young ones shall lie down, and the lion shall eat straw like the ox.
And the nursing child shall play upon the hole of the viper, and upon the den of the adder the weaned child shall stretch out his hand.
They shall not hurt nor destroy in all My holy mountain, for the earth shall be full of the knowledge of the LORD as the waters cover the sea.
And it shall come to pass in that day, that the root of Jesse, who stands as a banner for the peoples, to him shall the nations seek; and his resting place shall be glory.

And it shall come to pass in that day, that the Lord shall again stretch forth His hand a second time to reclaim the remnant of His people, that remains from Assyria, and from Egypt, and from Pathros, and from Cush, and from Elam, and from Shinar, and from Hamath, and from the coastlands of the sea.
And he shall lift up a banner for the nations, and shall gather the outcasts of Israel; and the dispersed of Judah he shall collect from the four corners of the earth.
The jealousy of Ephraim shall depart, and the adversaries of Judah shall be cut off; Ephraim shall not envy Judah, and Judah shall not vex Ephraim.

They shall swoop down upon the shoulder of the Philistines to the west; together they shall plunder the children of the east. Edom and Moab shall be the outstretching of their hand, and the children of Ammon their obedience.

And the LORD will utterly destroy the tongue of the sea of Egypt; and with the scorching of his wind he will wave his hand over the River, and will strike it into seven streams, and will cause men to cross over in sandals.
And there shall be a highway for the remnant of His people that shall remain from Assyria, as there was for Israel in the day that he came up out of the land of Egypt.
And you will say in that day, “I will give thanks to you, O LORD, for though you were angry with me, your anger has turned away, and you comfort me.”
Behold, God is my salvation; I will trust and not be afraid, for the LORD, the LORD, is my strength and song, and He has become my salvation.
Therefore with joy you shall draw water from the wells of salvation.
And you will say in that day, Give thanks to the LORD, call upon His name; make known His deeds among the peoples, remember that His name is exalted.
Sing to the LORD, for He has done gloriously; let this be made known in all the earth.
Cry aloud and shout for joy, O inhabitant of Zion, for great in your midst is the Holy One of Israel.
The burden concerning Babylon, which Isaiah son of Amoz saw.
On a bare mountain lift up a banner; raise the voice to them, wave the hand, that they may enter the gates of nobles.
I have commanded my consecrated ones, I have also summoned my mighty ones for my anger, those who exult in my majesty.
The sound of a tumult on the mountains, as of a great people; the noise of the uproar of kingdoms, of nations gathered together. The LORD of hosts is mustering the host for battle.
They come from a far land, from the end of the heavens, the LORD and the weapons of His indignation, to destroy the whole earth.
Wail, for the day of the LORD is near; as destruction from the Almighty it comes.
Therefore all hands will hang limp, and every human heart will melt.
And they shall be dismayed; pangs and sorrows shall seize them; they shall writhe like a woman in labor; they shall look in astonishment one at another; their faces shall be faces of flame.
Behold, the day of the LORD comes, cruel, with wrath and fierce anger, to make the land a desolation and to destroy its sinners from it.
For the stars of the heavens and their constellations will not give their light; the sun will be darkened in its going forth, and the moon will not cause its light to shine.
I will punish the world for its evil, and the wicked for their iniquity; I will put an end to the arrogance of the proud, and will bring low the haughtiness of the ruthless.
I will make mortal man more rare than fine gold, and humankind than the pure gold of Ophir.
Therefore I will shake the heavens, and the earth shall quake out of her place, in the fury of the LORD of hosts, and in the day of the burning of His anger.
And it shall be as a hunted gazelle, and as sheep with none to gather them; each man will turn to his own people, and each one will flee to his own land.
Everyone who is found shall be thrust through, and everyone who is caught shall fall by the sword.
Their little ones shall be dashed to pieces before their eyes; their houses shall be plundered, and their wives shall be ravished.
Behold, I am stirring up the Medes against them, who shall not regard silver, and as for gold, they shall not delight in it.
Their bows shall dash the young men to pieces, and they shall have no mercy on the fruit of the womb; their eye shall not spare the children.
And Babylon, the glory of kingdoms, the splendor of the pride of the Chaldeans, shall be as when God overthrew Sodom and Gomorrah.
It shall never again be inhabited, nor shall it be lived in from generation to generation; no Arab shall pitch his tent there, nor shall shepherds make their flocks lie down there.
But wild creatures shall lie down there, and their houses shall be full of howling beings; there ostriches shall dwell, and goat-demons shall dance there.
And coastlands shall answer in her desolate houses, and jackals in the palaces of delight; and her time is near to come, and her days shall not be prolonged.

For the LORD will have compassion on Jacob and will again choose Israel, and will set them in their own land; and the sojourner shall join himself to them, and they shall be added to the house of Jacob.

And peoples shall take them and bring them to their place, and the house of Israel shall possess them in the land of the LORD as male servants and female servants; and they shall take captive those who took them captive, and they shall rule over their oppressors.
And it shall come to pass in the day when the LORD gives you rest from your sorrow, and from your trouble, and from the hard service with which you were made to serve.
You shall take up this proverb against the king of Babylon, and say, How has the oppressor ceased, the insolent fury ceased!
The LORD has broken the staff of the wicked, the scepter of rulers.
He who struck the peoples in wrath with a stroke unrelenting, who ruled the nations in anger, pursued them without sparing.
The whole earth is at rest and quiet; they break forth into singing.
Even the cypresses rejoice over you, the cedars of Lebanon, saying, “Since you were laid low, no woodcutter comes up against us.”
Sheol from beneath is stirred up for you to meet you at your coming; it rouses for you the shades, all the leaders of the earth; it raises from their thrones all the kings of the nations.
All of them shall answer and say to you, “You too have become weak as we; you have been made like to us.”
Brought down to Sheol is your pride, the sound of your harps; beneath you a bed is spread of maggots, and worms are your covering.
How you are fallen from heaven, O shining one, son of the dawn! How you are cut down to the earth, you who laid low the nations.
But you said in your heart, “I will ascend to heaven; above the stars of God I will raise my throne, and I will sit on the mount of assembly, in the far reaches of the north.”
I will ascend above the heights of the clouds; I will make myself like the Most High.
Yet you shall be brought down to Sheol, to the uttermost depths of the pit.
Those who see you will gaze at you, they will ponder over you, saying, Is this the man who made the earth tremble, who shook kingdoms?
Who made the world like a wilderness, and overthrew its cities, who did not open the house of his prisoners.
All the kings of the nations, all of them, lie in glory, each in his own house.
But you are cast out from your grave like a loathed shoot, clothed with the slain, those pierced by the sword, who go down to the stones of the pit, like a trampled carcass.
You shall not be joined with them in burial, because you have destroyed your land, you have slain your people; the seed of evildoers shall never be named forever.
Prepare a slaughter-place for his sons because of the iniquity of their fathers, that they may not arise and possess the land, and fill the face of the world with cities.
And I will rise up against them, declares the LORD of hosts, and I will cut off from Babylon name and remnant, offspring and descendant, declares the LORD.
And I will make it a possession for the hedgehog, and pools of water; and I will sweep it with the broom of destruction, declares the LORD of hosts.
The LORD of hosts has sworn, saying, Surely as I have purposed, so shall it be; and as I have counseled, so shall it stand.
to break Assyria in My land, and upon My mountains tread him under foot; then his yoke shall depart from off them, and his burden shall be removed from off their shoulder.
This is the counsel that is purposed upon all the earth, and this is the hand that is stretched out upon all the nations.
For the LORD of hosts has purposed, and who shall annul it? And his hand is stretched out, and who shall turn it back?
In the year that King Ahaz died, this burden came.
Do not rejoice, O Philistia, all of you, because the rod that struck you is broken; for from the root of the serpent shall come forth a viper, and its fruit shall be a flying fiery serpent.
The firstborn of the poor shall feed, and the needy shall lie down in safety; and I will slay your root with famine, and your remnant shall be killed.
Wail, O gate; cry out, O city; melt away, O Philistia, all of you, for from the north smoke comes, and there is no straggler in his ranks.
And what shall one answer the messengers of the nation? That the LORD has founded Zion, and in her the afflicted of his people shall find refuge.
The burden of Moab: For in the night Ar of Moab is laid waste and brought to silence; for in the night Kir of Moab is laid waste and brought to silence.
He has gone up to the house and Dibon, to the high places, to weep; over Nebo and over Medeba Moab wails. On every head is baldness, every beard is shorn.
In her streets they gird themselves with sackcloth; on her housetops and in her squares everyone wails, going down weeping.
Heshbon cries out, and Elealeh; their voice is heard as far as Jahaz. Therefore the armed men of Moab shout; his soul trembles within him.

My heart cries out for Moab; her fugitives flee as far as Zoar, as a three-year-old heifer. For on the ascent of Luhith they go up with weeping; for on the way of Horonaim they raise a cry of destruction.
For the waters of Nimrim shall become desolations; for the grass is dried up, the tender herb is consumed, there is no green thing.
Therefore the abundance they have gained, and their treasure, they shall carry away to the brook of the willows.
For the cry has gone around the border of Moab; to Eglaim is her wailing, and to Beer-elim is her wailing.
For the waters of Dimon are full of blood; for I will bring upon Dimon yet more, a lion upon the remnant of Moab, and upon the survivors of the land.
Send the lamb to the ruler of the land, from Sela in the wilderness to the mount of the daughter of Zion.
And it shall be, like a wandering bird, a scattered nest, so shall the daughters of Moab be at the fords of Arnon.
Bring counsel, execute judgment; make your shadow as the night in the midst of noonday; hide the outcasts, do not betray the wanderer.
Let My outcasts of Moab sojourn with you; be a shelter for them from the face of the destroyer. For the oppressor is at an end, destruction is finished, the trampler is consumed out of the land.
And a throne shall be established in mercy, and upon it shall sit in truth, in the tent of David, one who judges and seeks justice and is swift in righteousness.
We have heard of the pride of Moab, that he is very proud, of his arrogance and his pride and his wrath; his boastings are not so.
Therefore Moab shall wail for Moab, all of it shall wail; for the raisin-cakes of Kir-hareseth you shall moan, utterly stricken.

For the fields of Heshbon languish, the vine of Sibmah; the lords of the nations have struck down its choice branches, which reached to Jazer, wandered through the wilderness; its shoots were spread abroad, they passed over the sea.

Therefore I will weep with the weeping of Jazer for the vine of Sibmah; I will drench you with my tears, O Heshbon and Elealeh, for upon your summer fruit and upon your harvest the shout of joy has fallen.

Joy and gladness are taken away from the fruitful field; and in the vineyards there shall be no singing, neither shall there be shouting. Wine in the winepresses shall none tread; I have made the shouting to cease.
Therefore my heart moans for Moab like a harp, and my inward parts for Kir-hareseth.
And it shall come to pass, when it is seen that Moab is wearied upon the high place, that he will come to his sanctuary to pray, but he shall not prevail.
This is the word that the LORD spoke concerning Moab in time past.

And now the LORD has spoken, saying, “Within three years, as the years of a hired worker, the glory of Moab shall be brought into contempt, with all his great multitude; and the remnant shall be very small and feeble.”
The burden of Damascus: Behold, Damascus is taken away from being a city, and shall become a ruinous heap.
The cities of Aroer are forsaken; they shall be for flocks, which shall lie down, and none shall make them afraid.
And the fortress shall cease from Ephraim, and the kingdom from Damascus, and the remnant of Aram shall be as the glory of the children of Israel, declares the LORD of hosts.
And it shall come to pass in that day, that the glory of Jacob shall be made thin, and the fatness of his flesh shall grow lean.
And it shall be as when one gathers the standing grain, and his arm reaps the ears; and it shall be as one who gleans ears of grain in the Valley of Rephaim.

Yet gleanings shall be left in it, as in the beating of an olive tree: two or three berries in the topmost bough, four or five in the branches of the fruitful one, declares the LORD, the God of Israel.
In that day man shall lean upon his Maker, and his eyes shall look to the Holy One of Israel.
And he shall not look to the altars, the work of his hands, neither shall he regard that which his fingers have made, the Asherim and the sun-pillars.
In that day his fortified cities shall be like the forsaken places of the forest and the hilltop, which they forsook before the children of Israel, and it shall be a desolation.
For you have forgotten the God of your salvation, and the Rock of your stronghold you have not remembered; therefore you plant pleasant plantings, and with a foreign vine you set it with slips.
In the day you plant, you make it grow, and in the morning you cause your seed to blossom; yet the harvest is a heap in the day of grief and incurable pain.
Ah, the uproar of many peoples, who roar like the roaring of the seas, and the tumult of nations, who crash like the crashing of mighty waters.

Nations shall roar like the roaring of many waters, but He will rebuke them, and they shall flee far away, and shall be chased like chaff of the mountains before the wind, and like whirling dust before the storm.
At eventide, behold, terror; before the morning, he is no more. This is the portion of those who plunder us, and the lot of those who spoil us.
Woe to the land of whirring wings, which is beyond the rivers of Cush.

That sends envoys by sea, and in vessels of papyrus upon the face of the waters, saying, “Go, swift messengers, to a nation drawn out and polished, to a people feared from this time and onward, a nation measured line by line and trodden down, whose land the rivers have plundered.”
All you inhabitants of the world, and you who dwell on the earth, when a banner is lifted up on the mountains, see; and when the trumpet is blown, hear.
For thus the LORD said to me, I will be still, and I will look on from My dwelling place, like clear heat in the sunshine, like a cloud of dew in the heat of harvest.

For before the harvest, when the blossom is complete and the ripening grape becomes a swelling cluster, he shall cut off the shoots with pruning knives, and the spreading branches he shall remove and cast away.
They shall be left together to the birds of the mountains and to the beasts of the earth; and the birds shall summer upon them, and all the beasts of the earth shall winter upon them.

At that time a gift shall be brought to the LORD of hosts: a people drawn out and polished, and from a people terrible from this time and onward, a nation measured line by line and trodden down, whose land the rivers have spoiled, to the place of the name of the LORD of hosts, Mount Zion.
The burden concerning Egypt: Behold, the LORD is riding on a swift cloud and is coming to Egypt; the idols of Egypt will tremble before Him, and the heart of Egypt will melt within it.
And I will stir up the Egyptians against the Egyptians, and they shall fight, each man against his brother and each man against his neighbor, city against city, kingdom against kingdom.
And the spirit of Egypt shall be emptied out within it, and I will confound its counsel; and they shall inquire of the idols, and of the charmers, and of the mediums, and of the spiritists.
And I will give Egypt over into the hand of cruel masters, and a fierce king shall rule over them, declares the Lord, the LORD of hosts.
The waters from the sea shall be dried up, and the river shall be parched and waste.
And the rivers shall stink; the streams of Egypt shall be diminished and dried up; the reeds and rushes shall wither.
The meadows by the Nile, by the mouth of the Nile, and all that is sown by the Nile shall dry up, be driven away, and be no more.
And the fishermen shall mourn, and all who cast the hook into the Nile shall lament, and those who spread the net upon the face of the waters shall languish.
And the workers in fine flax shall be ashamed, and the weavers of white cloth.
And her foundations shall be crushed; all who work for wages shall be grieved in soul.
Surely the princes of Zoan are utterly foolish; the wise counselors of Pharaoh give brutish counsel. How can you say to Pharaoh, “I am a son of the wise, a son of ancient kings”?
Where then are your wise men? Let them now declare to you, and let them know what the LORD of hosts has purposed concerning Egypt.
The princes of Zoan have become fools, the princes of Noph are deceived; they have led Egypt astray, the corner-stone of her tribes.
The LORD has mingled within her a spirit of confusion, and they have led Egypt astray in all her works, as a drunkard staggers in his vomit.
And there shall be no work for Egypt which head or tail, palm branch or reed, may do.
In that day Egypt shall be like women, and shall tremble and fear because of the shaking of the hand of the LORD of hosts, which He shakes over it.
And the land of Judah shall be a terror to Egypt; everyone who makes mention of it to him shall be afraid, because of the counsel of the LORD of hosts, which He has purposed against it.
In that day there shall be five cities in the land of Egypt speaking the language of Canaan and swearing to the LORD of hosts; one shall be called City of Destruction.
In that day there shall be an altar to the LORD in the midst of the land of Egypt, and a pillar at its border to the LORD.

And it shall be for a sign and for a witness to the LORD of hosts in the land of Egypt; for they shall cry to the LORD because of the oppressors, and He shall send them a savior and a mighty one, and He shall deliver them.
And the LORD shall be made known to Egypt, and the Egyptians shall know the LORD in that day, and they shall serve with sacrifice and offering, and shall vow a vow to the LORD and perform it.
And the LORD shall strike Egypt, striking and healing; and they shall return to the LORD, and He shall be entreated of them, and shall heal them.
In that day there shall be a highway from Egypt to Assyria, and the Assyrian shall come into Egypt, and the Egyptian into Assyria, and the Egyptians shall serve with the Assyrians.
In that day Israel shall be the third with Egypt and with Assyria, a blessing in the midst of the earth.
whom the LORD of hosts has blessed, saying, Blessed be Egypt My people, and Assyria the work of My hands, and Israel My inheritance.
In the year that the commander came to Ashdod, when Sargon king of Assyria sent him, and he fought against Ashdod and took it.

At that time the LORD spoke by the hand of Isaiah son of Amoz, saying, Go, and loose the sackcloth from upon your loins, and take your sandal from off your foot. And he did so, walking naked and barefoot.
And the LORD said, As my servant Isaiah has walked naked and barefoot three years for a sign and a wonder upon Egypt and upon Cush,
So shall the king of Assyria lead away the captives of Egypt and the exiles of Cush, young and old, naked and barefoot, with bared buttocks, the nakedness of Egypt.
And they shall be dismayed and ashamed of Cush their expectation, and of Egypt their glory.
And the inhabitant of this coastland shall say in that day, Behold, such is our expectation, to which we fled for help, to be delivered from the face of the king of Assyria; and how shall we escape?
The burden of the wilderness of the sea: as whirlwinds in the Negev sweep through, so it comes from the wilderness, from a terrible land.
A hard vision has been told to me: the traitor betrays, and the destroyer destroys. Go up, Elam; lay siege, Media; all her sighing I bring to an end.
Therefore my loins are filled with trembling; pangs have seized me like the pangs of a woman in labor. I am bent with anguish at the hearing; I am dismayed at the seeing.
My heart wanders; terror has startled me. The twilight of my desire he has turned for me into trembling.
The table is set, the watch is on the watchtower; eat, drink. Arise, you princes, anoint the shield.
For thus has my Lord said to me, Go, set a watchman; what he sees, let him declare.
And he saw a chariot with a pair of horsemen, a chariot of donkeys, a chariot of camels; and he listened with utmost heed, with very attentive listening.
And he cried, “A lion! Upon the watchtower, my lord, I stand continually by day, and upon my guard I am stationed all the nights.”
And behold, here comes a chariot of a man, with a pair of horsemen. And he answered and said, Fallen, fallen is Babylon, and all the carved images of her gods he has shattered to the ground.
O my threshed one and son of my threshing floor, that which I have heard from the LORD of hosts, the God of Israel, I have declared to you.
The burden of Dumah. One calls to me from Seir, “Watchman, what of the night? Watchman, what of the night?”
The watchman said, Morning comes, and also night. If you would inquire, inquire; return, come.
The burden concerning Arabia: In the thicket in Arabia you shall lodge, O caravans of Dedanites.
To meet the thirsty bring water, inhabitants of the land of Tema; with his bread meet the fugitive.
For before the swords they fled, before the drawn sword, and before the bent bow, and before the grievousness of war.
For thus has the Lord said to me, Within a year, according to the years of a hired worker, all the glory of Kedar shall come to an end.
And the remnant of the number of the bowmen, the mighty men of the sons of Kedar, shall be few; for the LORD, the God of Israel, has spoken.
The burden concerning the Valley of Vision: What ails you now, that you have all gone up to the housetops?
A city full of uproar, a tumultuous town, a joyous city! Your slain are not slain with the sword, nor are they dead in battle.
All your commanders fled together; they were bound by the bow. All who were found in you were bound together; from afar they had fled.
Therefore I said, “Turn away from me; I will weep bitterly. Do not hasten to comfort me over the ruin of the daughter of my people.”
For it is a day of tumult and of trampling and of confusion for the Lord, the LORD of hosts, in the Valley of Vision, a tearing down of wall and a cry to the mountain.
And Elam bore the quiver, with chariots of men and horsemen, and Kir uncovered the shield.
And it came to pass, your choicest valleys were filled with chariots, and the horsemen took their stand at the gate.
And he removed the covering of Judah, and you looked in that day to the armor of the House of the Forest.
And you saw the breaches of the city of David, that they were many, and you gathered together the waters of the lower pool.
You counted the houses of Jerusalem, and you broke down the houses to fortify the wall.
And you made a reservoir between the two walls for the water of the old pool, but you did not look to Him who made it, nor did you see Him who formed it long ago.
And in that day the Lord, the LORD of hosts, called for weeping and for mourning and for baldness and for girding with sackcloth.
But behold, joy and gladness, killing oxen and slaughtering sheep, eating flesh and drinking wine: “Eat and drink, for tomorrow we die.”
But it was revealed in my ears by the LORD of hosts: Surely this iniquity shall not be atoned for you until you die, says the Lord GOD of hosts.
Thus says the Lord GOD of hosts: Go, come to this steward, to Shebna who is over the house.
What have you here, and whom have you here, that you have hewn out for yourself a tomb here, you who hew your tomb on high, you who carve a dwelling for yourself in the rock?
Behold, the LORD will hurl you away with a mighty hurling, and will surely wrap you up.
He will surely whirl you away with a whirling, like a ball into a wide land; there you shall die, and there shall be the chariots of your glory, you disgrace of your master’s house.
And I will thrust you from your office, and from your station shall He pull you down.
And it shall come to pass in that day, that I will call my servant Eliakim the son of Hilkiah.

And I will clothe him with your tunic, and will strengthen him with your sash, and I will commit your authority into his hand; and he shall be a father to the inhabitant of Jerusalem and to the house of Judah.
And I will place the key of the house of David upon his shoulder; and he shall open, and none shall shut; and he shall shut, and none shall open.
And I will fasten him as a peg in a sure place, and he shall be for a throne of glory to his father’s house.
And they shall hang upon him all the glory of his father’s house, the offspring and the offshoots, all the small vessels, from the vessels of the bowls even to all the vessels of the lyres.

In that day, declares the LORD of hosts, the peg that was fastened in a sure place shall give way; it shall be cut down and fall, and the burden that was upon it shall be cut off, for the LORD has spoken.
The burden of Tyre. Wail, O ships of Tarshish, for it is laid waste, without house, without entering in; from the land of Kittim it is revealed to them.
Be still, you inhabitants of the coastland, you merchants of Sidon, whose messengers cross the sea and fill you.
And on many waters was the grain of Shihor, the harvest of the Nile, her revenue; and she became the merchandise of the nations.
Be ashamed, O Sidon, for the sea has spoken, the stronghold of the sea, saying, I have not travailed nor given birth, I have not reared young men nor brought up virgins.
When the report comes to Egypt, they shall writhe in anguish at the report of Tyre.
Pass over to Tarshish; wail, you inhabitants of the coastland.
Is this your exultant city, whose origin is from days of old, whose feet carried her far away to sojourn?
Who has purposed this against Tyre, the bestower of crowns, whose merchants were princes, whose traders were the honored of the earth?
The LORD of hosts has purposed it, to profane the pride of all splendor, to bring into contempt all the honored of the earth.
Pass through your land like the Nile, O daughter of Tarshish; there is no more restraint.
He stretched out His hand over the sea, He shook the kingdoms; the LORD has commanded concerning Canaan, to destroy her strongholds.
And he said, You shall no more continue to exult, O oppressed one, virgin daughter of Sidon. Arise, pass over to Kittim; even there you shall find no rest.
Behold, the land of the Chaldeans—this is the people that was not; Assyria founded it for desert-dwellers. They set up their siege-towers, they stripped its palaces, they made it a ruin.
Wail, O ships of Tarshish, for your stronghold is laid waste.
And it shall come to pass in that day that Tyre shall be forgotten seventy years, according to the days of one king; at the end of seventy years it shall be to Tyre as the song of the harlot.
Take a harp, go about the city, forgotten harlot; skillfully play, multiply song, that you may be remembered.

And it shall come to pass at the end of seventy years, that the LORD will visit Tyre, and she shall return to her hire, and shall commit fornication with all the kingdoms of the earth upon the face of the ground.

And her merchandise and her hire shall be holiness to the LORD; it shall not be treasured nor laid up, for her merchandise shall be for those who dwell before the LORD, to eat their fill and for stately clothing.
Behold, the LORD empties the earth and lays it waste, and distorts its face, and scatters its inhabitants.

And it shall be, as with the people, so with the priest; as with the servant, so with his master; as with the maid, so with her mistress; as with the buyer, so with the seller; as with the lender, so with the borrower; as with the creditor, so with him who is in his debt.
Utterly emptied shall the earth be emptied, and utterly plundered shall it be plundered; for the LORD has spoken this word.
The earth mourns and withers, the world languishes and withers; the exalted of the people of the earth languish.
And the earth is profaned under its inhabitants, for they have transgressed the laws, altered the statute, broken the everlasting covenant.
Therefore a curse has devoured the earth, and those who dwell in it are held guilty; therefore the inhabitants of the earth are burned, and few mortal men are left.
The new wine mourns, the vine languishes; all the merry-hearted sigh.
The mirth of timbrels has ceased, the uproar of the jubilant has ended, the joy of the harp has ceased.
They shall not drink wine with a song; strong drink shall be bitter to those who drink it.
The city of chaos is broken down; every house is shut up so that none may enter.
A cry for wine is in the streets; all joy is darkened, the gladness of the earth is gone.
Desolation is left in the city, and the gate is battered to ruins.
For thus it shall be in the midst of the earth among the peoples, as the shaking of an olive tree, as the gleanings when the vintage is ended.
They shall lift up their voice, they shall sing for joy; for the majesty of the LORD they shall cry aloud from the sea.
Therefore in the east give glory to the LORD; in the coastlands of the sea, to the name of the LORD, the God of Israel.

From the uttermost part of the earth we have heard songs: Glory to the righteous! But I said, My secret is mine, my secret is mine; woe is me! The treacherous have dealt treacherously; yea, with treachery the treacherous have dealt treacherously.
Terror and pit and snare are upon you, O inhabitant of the earth.

And it shall come to pass, that he who flees from the sound of the terror shall fall into the pit; and he who climbs up out of the midst of the pit shall be taken in the snare. For the windows on high are opened, and the foundations of the earth tremble.
Utterly broken is the earth; completely shattered is the earth; violently shaken is the earth.
The earth shall reel to and fro like a drunkard, and shall sway like a hut; and her transgression shall be heavy upon her, and she shall fall, and not rise again.
And it shall come to pass in that day, that the LORD will punish the host of the height on high, and the kings of the earth upon the earth.
And they shall be gathered together, as prisoners are gathered into the pit, and shall be shut up in the dungeon; and after many days they shall be visited.
Then the moon shall be confounded and the sun ashamed, for the LORD of hosts reigns on Mount Zion and in Jerusalem, and before His elders is glory.
O LORD, you are my God; I will exalt you, I will praise your name, for you have worked wonders, counsels from of old, faithfulness and truth.
For you have made a city a heap, a fortified town a ruin; the palace of strangers is a city no more, it shall never be built again.
Therefore a strong people shall honor you; the city of ruthless nations shall fear you.
For you have been a stronghold to the poor, a stronghold to the needy in his distress, a refuge from the storm, a shade from the heat; for the breath of the ruthless is like a storm against a wall.
Like the heat in a parched land you subdue the uproar of strangers; as the heat is brought low by the shadow of a cloud, so the song of the ruthless is silenced.
And the LORD of hosts will make for all the peoples on this mountain a feast of rich food, a feast of well-aged wine, of rich food full of marrow, of well-refined aged wine.
And He will swallow up in this mountain the face of the covering that is cast over all peoples, and the veil that is spread over all the nations.
He will swallow up death forever, and the Lord GOD will wipe away the tear from every face; and the reproach of His people He will remove from all the earth, for the LORD has spoken.
And it shall be said in that day, Behold, this is our God; we have waited for Him, and He will save us. This is the LORD; we have waited for Him; we will be glad and rejoice in His salvation.
For the hand of the LORD shall rest on this mountain, and Moab shall be trampled under Him, as straw is trodden down in the water of a dung-pit.
And he shall spread out his hands in the midst of it, as the swimmer spreads out his hands to swim; and he shall bring down his pride together with the craftiness of his hands.
And the fortress of the high walls he will bring down, lay low, and cast to the ground, even to the dust.
In that day this song shall be sung in the land of Judah: We have a strong city; he sets salvation for walls and rampart.
Open the gates, that the righteous nation may enter in, which keeps faithfulness.
You will keep in perfect peace the steadfast mind, because it trusts in you.
Trust in the LORD forever, for in Yah, the LORD, is an everlasting Rock.
For he has brought low those who dwell on high, the lofty city; he lays it low, he lays it low to the ground, he brings it down to the dust.
The foot shall trample it down, the feet of the poor, and the steps of the needy.
The path of the righteous is level; you, O Upright One, make straight the track of the righteous.
Indeed, in the path of Your judgments, O LORD, we have waited for You; for Your name and for the remembrance of You is the desire of our soul.
My soul longs for You in the night; indeed, my spirit within me seeks You earnestly. For when Your judgments are in the earth, the inhabitants of the world learn righteousness.
Though favor is shown to the wicked, he will not learn righteousness; in a land of uprightness he deals perversely, and does not behold the majesty of the LORD.
O LORD, your hand is lifted high, yet they do not see it; they shall see and be ashamed for the zeal for the people; yes, the fire of your adversaries shall devour them.
O LORD, you will ordain peace for us, for even all our works you have wrought for us.
O LORD our God, other lords besides You have ruled over us; but by You alone will we make mention of Your name.
The dead shall not live; the shades shall not rise. Therefore you have visited and destroyed them, and made all remembrance of them to perish.
You have increased the nation, O LORD, you have increased the nation; you are glorified, you have extended all the borders of the earth.
O LORD, in distress they sought You; they poured out a whispered prayer when Your chastening was upon them.
Like a woman with child, drawing near to give birth, writhes and cries out in her pangs, so were we before you, O LORD.
We were with child, we writhed in labor, as though we gave birth to wind; we have not wrought deliverance in the earth, nor have the inhabitants of the world fallen.
Your dead shall live; my corpses shall arise. Awake and sing for joy, you who dwell in the dust, for your dew is a dew of lights, and the earth will cast out the shades.
Come, my people, enter into your chambers, and shut your doors behind you; hide yourself for a little moment, until the indignation has passed by.
For behold, the LORD is coming forth from His place to punish the iniquity of the inhabitants of the earth upon them; and the earth shall disclose her blood, and shall no more cover her slain.
In that day the LORD, with his hard and great and strong sword, will punish Leviathan the fleeing serpent, Leviathan the twisting serpent, and he will slay the dragon that is in the sea.
In that day, a vineyard of delight—sing of her.
I, the LORD, am its keeper; every moment I water it, lest any harm visit it; night and day I guard it.
Wrath is not in Me. Oh that there were for Me briers and thorns in battle! I would march against them, I would burn them together.
Or let him take hold of my stronghold; he shall make peace with me, peace he shall make with me.
In days to come Jacob shall take root, Israel shall blossom and bud, and they shall fill the face of the world with fruit.
Has he struck him as he struck those who struck him? Or has he been slain as those he slew were slain?
In measure, by sending her away you contended with her; he removed her with his rough wind in the day of the east wind.

Therefore by this shall the iniquity of Jacob be atoned for, and this is all the fruit of removing his sin: when he makes all the stones of the altar like chalk stones beaten in pieces, the Asherim and the sun-pillars shall not stand.
For the fortified city is solitary, a habitation forsaken and cast away like a wilderness; there the calf shall graze, and there it shall lie down and consume its branches.

When its boughs are withered, they shall be broken; women come and set them alight. For it is a people without understanding; therefore its Maker will not have mercy on it, and its Former will show it no favor.
And it shall come to pass in that day, that the LORD will thresh from the flowing stream of the River to the brook of Egypt, and you shall be gathered one by one, O children of Israel.

And it shall come to pass in that day, that a great trumpet shall be blown, and those who were lost in the land of Assyria and the outcasts in the land of Egypt shall come, and they shall bow themselves to the LORD on the holy mountain at Jerusalem.
Woe to the proud crown of the drunkards of Ephraim, and to the fading flower of his glorious beauty, which is on the head of the fertile valley of those overcome with wine.
Behold, the Lord has one who is mighty and strong, like a storm of hail, a destroying tempest, like a storm of mighty overflowing waters; with the hand he casts it down to the earth.
With feet shall be trampled the crown of pride of the drunkards of Ephraim.

And the fading flower of his glorious beauty, which is on the head of the fat valley, shall be like the first-ripe fig before the summer, which whoever sees it, while it is yet in his hand, he swallows it down.
In that day the LORD of hosts shall be for a crown of glory and for a diadem of beauty to the remnant of his people.
And for a spirit of judgment to him who sits in judgment, and for strength to those who turn back the battle at the gate.

And these also have staggered with wine and have wandered in strong drink; priest and prophet have staggered with strong drink, they are swallowed up by wine, they have wandered because of strong drink; they stagger in vision, they stumble in judgment.
For all the tables are full of vomit and filth, so that there is no place.
Whom shall he teach knowledge, and whom shall he make to understand the message? Those weaned from the milk, those taken from the breasts.
For it is precept upon precept, precept upon precept; line upon line, line upon line; a little here, a little there.
For with stammering lips and with another tongue He will speak to this people.
He who said to them, “This is the rest; give rest to the weary, and this is the repose,” yet they were not willing to listen.

And the word of the LORD shall be to them, precept upon precept, precept upon precept, line upon line, line upon line, a little here, a little there; that they may go and stumble backward, and be broken, and snared, and taken.
Therefore hear the word of the LORD, you men of scoffing, rulers of this people who are in Jerusalem.

Because you have said, “We have cut a covenant with Death, and with Sheol we have made an agreement; when the overflowing scourge passes through, it shall not come to us, for we have made lies our refuge, and in falsehood have we hidden ourselves.”
Therefore thus says the Lord GOD: Behold, I am laying in Zion a stone, a tested stone, a precious cornerstone, a sure foundation; whoever believes will not be in haste.
And I will set justice for a measuring line, and righteousness for a plumb line; and hail shall sweep away the refuge of lies, and waters shall overflow the hiding place.
Your covenant with death shall be wiped away, and your vision with Sheol shall not stand; when the overflowing scourge passes through, you shall be for it a trampling-place.
As often as it passes through, it shall seize you; for morning by morning it shall pass through, by day and by night; and it shall be sheer terror to understand the report.
For the bed is too short to stretch oneself on it, and the covering too narrow when one gathers oneself up.
For as in Mount Perazim the LORD will rise up, as in the valley in Gibeon He will be stirred, to perform His work, His strange work, and to accomplish His service, His alien service.
So now, do not be mockers, lest your bonds be made strong; for a full end, and that determined, I have heard from the Lord, the LORD of hosts, upon all the earth.
Give ear and hear my voice; attend and hear my utterance.
Does the plowman plow all day to sow, does he continually open and break up his ground?
Is it not so, that when he has leveled its surface, he scatters dill and sows cummin, and puts wheat in rows, and barley in its appointed place, and spelt on its border?
For his God instructs him in right judgment and teaches him.
For the black cumin is not threshed with a sharp threshing sledge, nor is a cart wheel rolled over the cumin; but the black cumin is beaten out with a staff, and the cumin with a rod.
Bread grain is crushed, yet he does not thresh it forever; though he drives the wheel of his cart and his horses over it, he does not grind it to powder.
This also comes forth from the LORD of hosts; He is wonderful in counsel and great in wisdom.
Woe to Ariel, Ariel, the city where David encamped! Add year to year; let the feasts go round.
And I will distress Ariel, and there shall be mourning and lamentation, and she shall be to me as Ariel.
And I will encamp against you all around, and I will lay siege against you with a rampart, and I will raise up siegeworks against you.

You shall be brought low; from the earth you shall speak, and from the dust your utterance shall sink down; and your voice shall be like that of a ghost from the ground, and from the dust your speech shall whisper.
And the multitude of your strangers shall be like fine dust, and the multitude of the ruthless like chaff that passes away; and it shall be in an instant, suddenly.
You shall be visited by the LORD of hosts with thunder and with earthquake and a great noise, with whirlwind and tempest and a flame of devouring fire.
And the multitude of all the nations that wage war against Ariel, even all that fight against her and her stronghold, and that distress her, shall be as a dream, a vision of the night.

And it shall be as when a hungry man dreams, and behold, he is eating; but he awakes, and his soul is empty. And as when a thirsty man dreams, and behold, he is drinking; but he awakes, and behold, he is faint, and his soul is craving. So shall be the multitude of all the nations that fight against Mount Zion.
Linger and be astonished, gaze and be blinded; they are drunk, but not with wine, they stagger, but not with strong drink.
For the LORD has poured out upon you a spirit of deep sleep, and has shut your eyes; the prophets, and your heads, the seers, he has covered.
And the vision of all has become to you like the words of a sealed book, which they give to one who knows the writing, saying, “Read this, I pray you,” and he says, “I cannot, for it is sealed.”
And the book is delivered to one who does not know writing, saying, “Read this, I pray you,” and he says, “I do not know writing.”
And the Lord said, Because this people draws near with its mouth and honors Me with its lips, but its heart is far from Me, and their fear of Me is a commandment of men learned by rote.

Therefore, behold, I will again do marvelous work with this people, a wonder and a marvel; and the wisdom of their wise men shall perish, and the understanding of their men of understanding shall be hidden.
Woe to those who go deep to hide counsel from the LORD, and whose works are in the dark, and they say, “Who sees us, and who knows us?”

Your turning of things upside down! Shall the potter be reckoned as clay, that the thing made should say of its maker, “He did not make me,” and the thing formed say of its former, “He has no understanding”?
Is it not yet a very little while, and Lebanon shall be turned into a fruitful field, and the fruitful field shall be counted as a forest?
And in that day the deaf shall hear the words of a book, and out of gloom and out of darkness the eyes of the blind shall see.
And the meek shall again rejoice in the LORD, and the poor among men shall exult in the Holy One of Israel.
For the ruthless one shall come to an end, and the scoffer shall be consumed, and all who watch for iniquity shall be cut off.
Those who make a man an offender by a word, and lay a snare for him who reproves in the gate, and turn aside the righteous with a thing of nought.
Therefore thus says the LORD to the house of Jacob, who redeemed Abraham: Jacob shall not now be ashamed, neither shall his face now grow pale.
For when he sees his children, the work of My hands in his midst, they will sanctify My name; they will sanctify the Holy One of Jacob, and will stand in awe of the God of Israel.
And those who err in spirit shall come to understanding, and those who murmur shall learn instruction.
Woe to rebellious children, declares the LORD, who devise counsel, but not from Me, and who pour out a molten covering, but not of My Spirit, in order to add sin upon sin.
Who set out to go down to Egypt, and did not ask at My mouth, to take refuge in the stronghold of Pharaoh, and to shelter in the shadow of Egypt.
And the stronghold of Pharaoh shall become to you for shame, and the shelter in the shadow of Egypt for reproach.
For his princes are at Zoan, and his envoys have reached Hanes.
All are ashamed of a people that cannot profit them, not for help and not for benefit, but for shame and also for reproach.
